moxie

Interface Expectation<E extends Expectation<E,R>,R>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Cardinality<E>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    ClassExpectation<T>, LambdaExpectation<R>, ObjectExpectation<T>

    public interface Expectation<E extends Expectation<E,R>,R>
extends Cardinality<E>
    Domain-specific language methods for setting out the details of a mock object expectation.

     

    Syntax Overview

    A typical Moxie expectation statement on a mock object looks like this:

    Moxie.expect(mock).willReturn("someValue").atLeastOnce().on().someMethod(Moxie.leq(42));
    It can be understood in four parts:

    The first bit: identify the mock
    We specify the mock or spy object on which we want to set an expectation. This is usually done using the Moxie.expect() method, though we can also use the Moxie.stub() method to create a stub, i.e. an expectation that won't affect the test if it doesn't get fulfilled.
    The middle bit: set conditions and behaviors
    Using the methods on the ObjectExpectation interface, we attach various conditions and behaviors to the expectation - when and how many times we expect the method to be called, what to return/throw/do when this happens, etc. See the next section for an overview of the different categories of methods. Note that methods that go in this section of an expectation statement can appear in any order.
    The penultimate bit: create a proxy
    This returns a proxy object of the same type as the mock, on which we invoke the method we expect to be called. Note that this may be done using the ObjectExpectation.on(), ObjectExpectation.when() or ObjectExpectation.will() methods. They perform exactly the same function; which you choose to call in any given situation is a matter of aesthetics.
    The last bit: specify the method
    We call the method we expect will be called on the mock, with the parameters to be expected. Note that you can use calls to MoxieMatchers to do flexible matching on method parameters (specifying that a parameter can contain any value, will be less/greater than a certain value, will contain a certain substring, etc.) - see method descriptions on that class for more details.
    The syntax for setting expectations on static methods and constructors is slightly different, but reads similarly - see documentation on the ClassExpectation interface for further detail:

    Moxie.expect(SomeClass.class).times(2).andReturn("wibble").on("aStaticMethod", Moxie.gt(5));
    Moxie.expect(SomeClass.class).once().onNew("constructor args", Moxie.hasSubstring("or matchers"));
    Finally, LambdaExpectations let one set expectations on static methods and constructors with a refactorable syntax that goes well with Java 8 lambdas. (You can of course use this on older versions of Java, but the corresponding anonymous-inner-class syntax is more cumbersome.) Some examples:

    Moxie.expect().willReturn("someValue").atLeastOnce().on(() -> { mock.someMethod(Moxie.leq(42)); });
    Moxie.expect().times(2).andReturn("wibble").on(() -> { SomeClass.aStaticMethod(Moxie.gt(5)); });
    Moxie.expect().once().on(() -> { new SomeClass("constructor args", Moxie.hasSubstring("or matchers")); });
     

    Conditions and Behaviors

    The "middle bit" of the expectation statement can contain zero or more condition/expectation setting methods:

    setting the expected number of invocations (Cardinality methods)
    The Expectation interface extends the Cardinality interface; methods from this interface (like never(), atLeastOnce(), atLeast(int), atMost(int)) can be used to specify how many times we expect this method call to be received.

    If none of these methods are invoked, the default behavior is once().

    setting stub behavior
    We can specify what the mock object will do when the method is called using the andReturn(), andThrow(), andDelegateTo() and andHandleWith() methods. (Note that these methods have the aliases willReturn(), willThrow(), willDelegateTo() and willHandleWith(), respectively; they do exactly the same thing as their similarly-named cousins.)

    Note that on spy objects, calling one of these methods specifies behavior that will be performed instead of delegating to the underlying object. If you wish to verify that the underlying object returns/throws something, read on.

    If none of these methods are invoked, the default behavior for mocks is to do nothing on void methods and return the default value (null for objects, zero/false for primitives) on non-void methods; for spies, the default behavior is to delegate to the same method on the object being spied upon.

    setting stub behavior on consecutive calls
    Sometimes we want the method to exhibit different behavior on consecutive calls - for instance, an iterator may return a series of different values as it traverses a collection. The andConsecutivelyReturn() method can be used for this purpose. Similarly, andConsecutivelyThrow() will specify a series of Throwables to be thrown on successive method calls. (These methods have the aliases willConsecutivelyReturn() and willConsecutivelyThrow() respectively.)

    If we want to mix and match returning values and throwing Throwables on consecutive calls, we can accomplish this by calling multiple behavior-setting methods within an expectation statement. For example, to get a method to return the value 1, then throw an Exception, then return the value "three" across three consecutive calls, use the following:

    Moxie.expect(mock).andReturn(1).andThrow(new Exception("Two!")).andReturn("three").times(3).on().someMethod();
    This works equally effectively as the "consecutively" methods described above, which are essentially just shorthand for this longer notation.

    verifying returned/thrown values (spies only)
    On spy objects, you can use the andVerifyReturn() and andVerifyThrow() methods (and their aliases, willReturnVerified() and willThrowVerified()) to check that the object spied upon returns/throws a given value. You can use MoxieMatchers methods to perform a flexible match.

    Note that these methods only make any sense on spy objects; if used on mock objects, they will throw an error.

    associating expectations with a Group: inGroup()
    The inGroup() method makes an expectation part of a Group, allowing us to verify the ordering of a set of calls across mocks, or to verify a partial set of expectations midway through the test. See the discussion and examples in the summary javadoc of the Group interface for more details.

    specifying that ordering doesn't matter: atAnyTime() (ORDERED mocks only)
    Mocks/spies created with the ORDERED option verify the order in which method calls are received. By calling atAnyTime() when setting up the expectation, we can specify that order checking will not be performed on this expectation. This call is meaningless on UNORDERED mocks.

     

    Subclasses

    Note that most of the useful methods on this class have been migrated to one of its three subclasses - please see the documentation of these classes for more detail:

    • ObjectExpectation - for setting expectations on most mock/spy objects in the traditional manner.
    • ClassExpectation - for expectations on static/constructor methods (reflection-based API).
    • LambdaExpectation - lets one specify mock calls (either on individual mocks or to statics/constructors) using Java 8 lambda syntax.

      • inGroup

        E inGroup(Group... groups)
        Specifies that this expectation should comprise part of the given group(s).
        Parameters:
        groups - one or more Groups created by MoxieControl.group()
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • atAnyTime

        E atAnyTime()
        Specifies that this expectation may be fulfilled at any time.

        Only meaningful for ORDERED mocks - expectations on which atAnyTime() is called will not be checked as part of the mock's call ordering.

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • willReturn

        E willReturn(R result)
        When a call fulfilling this expectation is received, return the given value.

        Note that willReturn() and andReturn() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        result - the value to be returned
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • willDoNothing

        E willDoNothing()
        When a call fulfilling this expectation is received, do nothing. This is most meaningful with void methods on spy objects; in these cases, the underlying method on the spy object is not called.

        Note that willDoNothing() and andDoNothing() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining
